comments.raw_text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; it; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; it; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13

I found this bug using phpmyadmin, I think it's related to cookies.

The browser has problems handling cookies with same identifier within the same site.

To reproduce the bug:
Use phpMyAdmin 3.3.9 configured with more than one mysql server. Login to the first server (for example as root), and then switch to another server. You couldn't login anymore to any of the servers with the same user. After cleaning cookies you could login again.

Other browsers work well (Opera 11, Internet Explorer 8)

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Login into phpMyAdmin 3.3.9 to one server (configured with at least two servers with same ip address but different port)
2. Switch server
3. You can't login anymore
Actual Results:  
The browser sends the wrong cookie content to the server
comments.creator: giacomo.arru@betatechnologies.it
comments.author: giacomo.arru@betatechnologies.it

I found this bug using phpmyadmin, I think it's related to cookies.

The browser has problems handling cookies with same identifier within the same site.

To reproduce the bug:
Use phpMyAdmin 3.3.9 configured with more than one mysql server. Login to the first server (for example as root), and then switch to another server. You couldn't login anymore to any of the servers with the same user. After cleaning cookies you could login again.

Other browsers work well (Opera 11, Internet Explorer 8)

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Login into phpMyAdmin 3.3.9 to one server (configured with at least two servers with same ip address but different port)
2. Switch server
3. You can't login anymore

The browser sends the wrong cookie content to the server

comments.creator: cedric@gn.apc.org
comments.author: cedric@gn.apc.org
comments.raw_text:
Since this involves problems logging into phpMyAdmin, it may be a duplicate of bug 618835 and so fixed by the patches to phpMyAdmin or Firefox there.  Does the failure to log in also happen with Firefox 3.5?  Could you provide a bit more detail about the phpMyAdmin configuration (what do you mean exactly by "switch server"?), and ideally real URLs?  How about some information from the Live HTTP Headers plugin, or https://developer.mozilla.org/en/HTTP_Logging?  Do the two phpMyAdmin URLs involved necessarily have the same hostname but a different port?

bug 618835 turned out to be a problem not with cookies but with a cached page being fetched, when FF 3.5 and other browsers revalidate the cache.  Please try one or both of those patches and see if the problem remains.  However, it could instead be a collision from storing cookies per-host rather than per-host-and-port, which again might only manifest since a bug in FF 3.5 was fixed (dealing with Cache-Control and Expires headers from PHP's private setting).

Since this involves problems logging into phpMyAdmin, it may be a duplicate of bug 618835 and so fixed by the patches to phpMyAdmin or Firefox there.  Does the failure to log in also happen with Firefox 3.5?  Could you provide a bit more detail about the phpMyAdmin configuration (what do you mean exactly by "switch server"?), and ideally real URLs?  How about some information from the Live HTTP Headers plugin, or https://developer.mozilla.org/en/HTTP_Logging?  Do the two phpMyAdmin URLs involved necessarily have the same hostname but a different port?

bug 618835 turned out to be a problem not with cookies but with a cached page being fetched, when FF 3.5 and other browsers revalidate the cache.  Please try one or both of those patches and see if the problem remains.  However, it could instead be a collision from storing cookies per-host rather than per-host-and-port, which again might only manifest since a bug in FF 3.5 was fixed (dealing with Cache-Control and Expires headers from PHP's private setting).
